nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and IAMs substantially underestimate economic damages from climate change and therefore should not be used to evaluate climate risks or guide policy
Prominent economic damage estimates (e.g. Nordhaus DICE and many studies cited by IPCC AR5) predict relatively trivial global GDP losses even for large temperature increases
Nordhaus DICE damage function is quadratic D(DeltaT)=a * DeltaT^2 with a approximately 0.00227, implying ~2.1% loss at 3C and ~7.9% at 6C
Economists commonly neglect climate tipping points or assign them negligible probability, contradicting climate science findings
Climate science (Lenton et al. and subsequent work) identifies multiple tipping elements plausibly triggerable this century and tipping cascades that amplify impacts and risks
A frequent methodological error is treating only weather-exposed sectors as vulnerable and assuming 'indoor' or 'controlled environment' sectors (roughly 87% in Nordhaus 1991) are negligibly affected
Nordhaus 1991 sector breakdown labels manufacturing, services and government as 'negligible effect' and omits systemic pathways (wildfires, supply chains, habitability, input shortages)
Using spatial correlations of current temperature and regional income as proxies for future climate change impacts is methodologically flawed

Statistical and cross-sectional methods (Mendelsohn, Burke, others) infer temperature-GDP relationships from spatial or historical time-series and then extrapolate them to 21st century warming, ignoring different physics, adaptation limits, and tipping risks

The DICE model is built on the Ramsey growth framework with Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous productivity and full employment assumptions, saddle-path stability, and an explicit abatement-damage trade-off
DICE links emissions -> atmospheric concentration -> radiative forcing -> DeltaT -> damage D(DeltaT), and adds abatement costs that reduce net output available for consumption and investment

Sensitivity experiments show that under much larger damage coefficients DICE still produces recovery and cannot generate an economic collapse; for extreme damage coefficients it becomes numerically infeasible rather than produce collapse
Integrated Assessment Models and policy metrics (DICE, FUND, PAGE, social cost of carbon) are calibrated to the flawed empirical estimates and thus inherit underestimation biases

Given the conceptual and methodological flaws and the inability of DICE to produce collapse outcomes, economists' published damage estimates and models calibrated to them should be rejected for assessing climate risk and informing policy

Epistemological factors in economics (Friedman-style permissive view of unrealistic assumptions and a small, insular refereeing community) helped normalise these flawed methods and prevented critical challenge
